headline: Defense Stocks Jump After Trump Calls for $1.5 Trillion Defense Budget
summary: U.S. defense companies rallied premarket after President Trump called for a $1.5 trillion defense budget, more than $500 billion more than the Pentagon is expected to receive this fiscal year.  Trump said the increased budget was necessary “especially in these very troubled and dangerous times,” in a social-media post late Wednesday.  Shares of Northrop Grumman, Lockheed Martin, and RTX each jumped 4.5% or more in premarket trading.

content.title: Defense Stocks Jump After Trump Calls for $1.5 Trillion Defense Budget
content.summary: U.S. defense companies rallied premarket after President Trump called for a $1.5 trillion defense budget, more than $500 billion more than the Pentagon is expected to receive this fiscal year.  Trump said the increased budget was necessary “especially in these very troubled and dangerous times,” in a social-media post late Wednesday.  Shares of Northrop Grumman, Lockheed Martin, and RTX each jumped 4.5% or more in premarket trading.

headline: Trump Demands More Defense Spending But Threatens Biggest Contractors
summary: The apparently contradictory string of announcements sent shares of major defense contractors tumbling as traders sought to interpret the White House’s intentions — and whether they would ever come to pass.  It all began with a demand that hit on a long-time issue for Trump: Major defense contractors that work with the government must end stock buybacks, stop issuing dividends and cap executive pay at $5 million a year until they invest more in factories and research to speed development.  Hours later, Trump signed an executive order codifying the decision.

content.title: Trump Demands More Defense Spending But Threatens Biggest Contractors
content.summary: The apparently contradictory string of announcements sent shares of major defense contractors tumbling as traders sought to interpret the White House’s intentions — and whether they would ever come to pass.  It all began with a demand that hit on a long-time issue for Trump: Major defense contractors that work with the government must end stock buybacks, stop issuing dividends and cap executive pay at $5 million a year until they invest more in factories and research to speed development.  Hours later, Trump signed an executive order codifying the decision.

headline: US markets lower before the bell after hot start to the year
summary: U.S. markets are pointing lower before the opening bell as the optimism that seemed kicked off the new year fades. Futures for the S&P 500 declined 0.2% Thursday, while Dow Jones Industrial Average futures lost 0.4%. Nasdaq futures were off 0.3% before the bell.

content.title: US markets lower before the bell after hot start to the year
content.summary: U.S. markets are pointing lower before the opening bell as the optimism that seemed kicked off the new year fades. Futures for the S&P 500 declined 0.2% Thursday, while Dow Jones Industrial Average futures lost 0.4%. Nasdaq futures were off 0.3% before the bell.

headline: Boeing, Defense Stocks Rally After Trump Calls for Huge Defense Budget
summary: U.S. defense companies rallied premarket after President Trump called for a $1.5 trillion defense budget, more than $500 billion more than the Pentagon is expected to receive this fiscal year.  Trump said the increased budget was necessary “especially in these very troubled and dangerous times,” in a social-media post late Wednesday.  Shares of Northrop Grumman, Lockheed Martin, L3Harris and RTX jumped between 3% and 8%.

headline: Defense Stocks Soar Again as Trump Plans Military Budget Boost
summary: A Goldman Sachs Group Inc. basket of European defense stocks rose as much as 3.8% on Thursday, extending its gain for the week to about 13%.  In the US, Northrop Grumman Corp. and Lockheed Martin Corp. surged more than 6% in premarket trading, rebounding from a drop the previous day when Trump called for curbs on executive pay and shareholder returns in the sector.  Defense stocks also rose in Asia.

content.title: Defense Stocks Soar Again as Trump Plans Military Budget Boost
content.summary: A Goldman Sachs Group Inc. basket of European defense stocks rose as much as 3.8% on Thursday, extending its gain for the week to about 13%.  In the US, Northrop Grumman Corp. and Lockheed Martin Corp. surged more than 6% in premarket trading, rebounding from a drop the previous day when Trump called for curbs on executive pay and shareholder returns in the sector.  Defense stocks also rose in Asia.

headline: Defense Stocks Surge as Trump Floats Pentagon Budget Boost
summary: In the US, Northrop Grumman Corp. and Lockheed Martin Corp. surged at least 9.3% before paring some gains, rebounding from Wednesday’s drop sparked by Trump’s demands to limit executive pay and shareholder returns.  A Goldman Sachs Group Inc. basket of European defense stocks rose as much as 3.8% Thursday, extending its gain for the week to about 15%.  The rally comes after Trump demanded a $500 billion increase in annual defense spending to $1.5 trillion, which would require Congressional approval.

content.title: Defense Stocks Surge as Trump Floats Pentagon Budget Boost
content.summary: In the US, Northrop Grumman Corp. and Lockheed Martin Corp. surged at least 9.3% before paring some gains, rebounding from Wednesday’s drop sparked by Trump’s demands to limit executive pay and shareholder returns.  A Goldman Sachs Group Inc. basket of European defense stocks rose as much as 3.8% Thursday, extending its gain for the week to about 15%.  The rally comes after Trump demanded a $500 billion increase in annual defense spending to $1.5 trillion, which would require Congressional approval.
